userreviews.userReview: Best-selling Author Karen Kingsbury has created a touching reminder that the years of childhood fly too quickly by us.Most of us faithfully remember and capture our children's "firsts." Karen encourages readers to try to recognize and savor the often-fleeting "lasts" - those milestones that so easily go unrecorded. The illustration by Mary Collier provide a lighthearted portrayal of everyday family life .... pictures we can all relate to. You and your children of all ages will smile, laugh, and maybe even shed a tear over them together. Let Me Hold You Longer is a heartwarming reminder of the precious process of growing up and the joys of watching it happen.Quote:The last time when I shout that yes, your room is still a mess.The last time that you need me for a ride from here to there.The last time that you spend the night with your old tattered bear.Let me hold on longer, God, to every precious last.

Incredibly sweet story written by a mother of six which reminds all parents to treasure each moment we spend with our children. As parents, we are usually so good about recording 'firsts', i.e., first tooth, step, word, grade, soccer goal, car, etc., but we often forget to notice 'lasts': last bottle, nap, bouquet of dandelions, sticky kiss, bed-time story, camp-out . . . all those little joys of childhood which are what make being a mother--or a father--the best job in the world and are over before we know it. Karen Kingsbury puts the question to us, "What would you do if you knew this was going to be the last time your child did ______?"And yet, despite the title, it's not about holding on to our children, just about cherishing what we hold now, realizing how quickly the present slips away. For a real treat, listen to the author read the poem-story aloud and tell about the inspiration behind it in this short YouTube clip.

Remembering your last with your child. Remembering the last you are able to hold them in your arms, carry them around, dance with them, (my personal favorite), drive them to lessons, go to band competitions, orchestra competitions, etc., etc.. My children are all grown up and do not need me as much, which is bitter sweet of it all. You raise them to love the Lord, and love people, then they are on their own, making their own decisions. Will be buying this book for my grandchildren.

SWEET STORY!!! Let Me Hold You Longer is a story about the precious moments we have in life. This story is told from the perspective of a mom who thinks about the lifetime of her sons lasts. It begins from the very beginning when he is born to when he heads off to college. Some examples of the lasts are the the last time you wore your faded baseball cap, last bat at little league, last piano lesson and the last time you were your high school football jersey. This our just a few of the examples that are throughout the book. This book is a precious story that is happy and sad all at once. As I read it I think about the many lasts that I had in my life and realize how quickly life goes by. We need to truly make the most of every minute and to cherish the times with out families. Also the artistry throughout was wonderful; very clean and crisp. I think that this would be good for students and parents, its a reminder of the joy of growing up and the experience the parents have of watching it.

This book is overall a good book that has to do with growing up. The book message is a good one for kids who do not always necessarily realize how fast life actually goes by. The book teaches or highlights how as you grow there are things that you will do for the last time. For example, the last time sleeping in a crib, the last time you hit a ball off of a tee, or the last time you go to high school. The thing I did not particularly like all that much about this book, is the art. The art sort of loses a disconnect with the children because it looks dark, is plain, and does not necessarily look like the art of a children's book.

This is a very sentimental book about a mother reflecting on all of the moments in her children's lives that will mark the last time that they do various childhood activities. It is a very sweet book, but I feel like it is geared more toward parents than children. However, I do think that a child would still enjoy it because of the fun illustrations that help tell the story. This is a book that I probably wouldn't highlight in a classroom because of the nature of the theme. This just seems like a book that would be good for a mom to read with her kids.

This book looks at life and how we start as kids, getting help from our parents, and eventually, the tables have turned and we are taking care of our parents. 3 topic ideas: Family - Healthy relationships, love Rhyme Growing up, responsibility

Absolutely beautiful book about the lasts in a person's life. We focus on the first (first step, first birthday etc) but rarely think of the last (last bottle, last diaper, last lost tooth, etc). It is bittersweet and lovely.

I thoroughly enjoyed "Let Me Hold You Longer" by Kingsbury however, I felt as though this book was geared towards parents rather than a classroom of students. This book touches on life's precious moments- starting in infancy and developing through various achievements that a child may accomplish. Kingsbury, through simple poetic writing, reminds parents to not only celebrates the "firsts" in a child's life but celebrate and hold on to the "lasts". Kingsbury has a special way with words and this book is no exception. She emphasizes the theme of holding onto your child(ren), as made evident by the title of the book, cherishing the moments that you don't realize are the "lasts". I am not a parent so I can only imagine how touching this picture book might be for parents watching their children navigate their way through life. I thought this book was sweet however, I'm not sure if I would place it in my classroom library. As elementary school students, they may not fully grasp the concept of how important their accomplishments are to their parents. It would be interesting to have each child bring the book home for a day or two and to have the student come back and tell their classmates the reaction their parents had to this book.

This book is great for the classroom, and it makes you really thankful for your mom. It is about this mom who starts out by holding her baby and thinking about the future things that she will get to see her child do and not know if it is her last. She talks about rocking him to sleep, telling him to clean his room, watching him play baseball and going off to college. She says in the end "Let me hold on longer, God, to every precious last. Time is precious and so are memories.

This book follows a mother and her wish to hold onto all of the "lasts" in her son's life. As her son grows up, the mother realizes just how fast he is growing, and wants to cherish each moment while she can. Her son goes through school and various phases of life, but at the end, he leaves for college. It is then that his mother is hit with reality and starts to reminisce about all of the precious moments when her son was still a little boy. I really liked this book! The story was very sweet, and it made me realize how true it is. As a college student, I find myself sometimes looking back on moments from high school and my childhood that really stood out to me. It made me realize how hard it is for mothers to send their children away to college when they still see them as their "little boy" or "little girl".I could use this book in a classroom because the students would be able to relate to it very well. Every child experiences growing up, and every parent experiences seeing their child grow up; so it would be a good book to read about family and how family is a precious thing in life.

This book is from a mother's point of view. She speaks in rhymes, talking about looking towards the future of her son's possible "lasts" in their relationship. She goes through the years all the way to his last day at home when he leaves for college.I really loved this book. It gave me chills and almost made me cry, just because it made me realize how time has flown in my life and I remember from my childhood all of those times that the mother mentions about his childhood. I don't have children, but I can imagine how touching and emotional this could make a parent feel, especially a mother. It reminds us that time flies by and each moment is special and should not be taken for granted. I would read this to my class to help them realize that someone loves them and it is important to make special memories even when they are small moments.

I chose this book to put on my top ten book shelf because I feel that this book is perfect for all ages. Whether its for a child who is growing up, going through the motions of change, or an adult who is watching their child grow up everyday, missing the things that one day will be gone. This book talks about a mother recognizing all the last things she will be doing, from birth to adulthood, when her son moves out and goes to college. My mother had bought me and my older brother this book for Christmas, and the first time I read it, it brought tears to my eyes. Growing up is difficult, and often it happens way to fast. This book does a lovely job to remind readers to value on the little things before they are gone. Love Love Love this book, great book for anyone.

Let Me Hold You Longer is the thoughts of a Mom as she watches her little boy grow and thinks ahead to the future. It's sweet and a little bit sappy, too. The illustrations are simply adorable and may even bring a tear to you eye as you read.While it is a lovely book, I think the Mother may enjoy it more than the child. However, it's written in poem and an enjoyable read no matter what. I personally think it is a good bedtime story since it has a more somber and calming tone to it along with gentle, yet eye-capturing pictures.* * * * *Published by TyndaleISBN: 1-4143-0055-7Listed for $14.99

Get your tissues when you read this. I started crying on the second page. (I'm so sentimental.) It's a sweet little picture book written from a mother to her son. She thinks about all the time she spends during his life looking for his "firsts": first word, first day of school, first day on the team. And then she realizes that along the way she has missed a lot of his "lasts": last time he came to her bed in the night to sleep, last page he colored for her, last time he asked her for romantic advice. It just hits so close to home. I want to try to do better to enjoy both the "firsts" and the "lasts."

This book is more for the adults then for the kids. I can't read it with out crying. Heard the author read/recite this book at a conference and there was not a dry eye in the place. If only we, parents or grandparents, knew when the last time is that we do a certain something with the special gift the God gave us. Would we treasure it a little more? In saying this, I will treasure every single minute that I am with my grandchildren. Even when they need to be disciplined. You may never have that moment with them again. Treasure it while you can.

This is clearly intended for adult readers, generally parents, at critical life transitions. It is poignant and appealing for that purpose. I can see it appealing to a very young child for the visuals and the lyrical, rhyming text, but most children beyond toddlers will not "get it" and might even have reactions of anxiety and/or irritability. Trying to think back to my own childhood, I feel it might have been seen as somewhat clinging. Just to be clear, though, I am NOT a fan of Silverstein's THE GIVING TREE.

This has to be one of my top ten picture books. I got this book when Nicole was little and potty training, after reading it my whole attitude changed. Reading this book helped me to realize that while we are busy celebrating all the firsts in the life of our children, the lasts are just around the corner. It is so important that we hold them a little longer, well at least as long as they'll let us.

This book hit me right where i live....Wow! If you want a childrens book that is really for you, this is it!! Trying to catch those last things...is the hardest...last time my son hugged me before he turned into a teenager, the last time my daughter said you know everything mom....lol. We always remember the firsts' - but what about the last time ...before they grew up ...and moved away. Great Book!

OK, yes I know this is a children's book, but this was a gift from my Aunt Wese and she said she automatically thought of me and Scott when she read this book in the store and I would agree. Actually, I would say any mother should read this book - especially mothers of young children to help them remember the lasts as much as the firsts (read the book and you will understand this). May God continue to bless all the mothers out there.

I'm not a mushy person - I rarely cry. And I don't really like the feely-good stories (like on sounds of sunday). But I read this to Ellie today and she kept saying, "Mom, quit crying!" I love this book because it gives perspective. If I read it every day I would have much more patience as a mother. In fact I think I'm going to buy it -- and I want to buy copies for all the parents and grandparents I know! HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

This book will tear your heart right in two. I can't get through it without crying as it talks about all the lasts a mother will experience with her child. Despite the tears, it's a beautiful and emotional story that serves as a reminder not to take the little moments for granted. I'll hug my baby extra long tonight as I think about all of his lasts I'll witness.

Bawled like a baby reading this to my kids. Fantastic book and one that the mothers out there will have a hard time finishing. We all know our babies will grow up but to read it put in such poetic phrases and to go through the chronological order of our child's life...it was beautiful and touching and made me want to hug them even tighter.

This book is from the a mothers point of view. It explains the relationship she has with her son as she watches him grow up. By the end of this picture book, you will have had yourself a good cry. That is Not a common thing to say about a picture book, I know. If you read it, and you'll know what I mean. :)

This is the sweetest kids book ever. I can barely get through it without crying when she talks about how she never got the chance to enjoy the lasts of her children because she didnt know it would be the last time they, crawled, drank from a bottle, asked for help with homework, scored a goal etc. Love it!

Every mom should read this book, alone, with a big box of kleenex. It'll make you look for, not the firsts, but the lasts. You just might find yourself savoring hugs, or those night that child climbs into bed with you again, or those crazy hectic mornings just a little bit more. You never know, it could be the last.

Very good! I don't have young children, but I'm a Karen Kingsbury fan. This is a book about "lasts", rather than a child's firsts. It was reflective and a bit heartbreaking because my last child is entering his last year in grade school. :(

Children grow up too fast, and before you know it, you're tying their shoe for the last time, arranging their last play date, or attending their last school conference. This book is a great reminder to cherish every moment.

I know it's a kid book, but if you have kids (especially boys) this book will really touch your heart. It makes me wonder if I am really paying attention to my kids as they grow instead of just going on autopilot and waiting for certain stages to pass.

Sweet book that is a tear jerker for any mom who knows her kids are growing up too fast. It is a good reminder to savor each day and the time with our children because their "lasts" come all to quickly!

description: 2005 Logos Bookstores Award winner for Best Children's Book With lighthearted illustrations and a sweet, reflective tone, best-selling author Karen Kingsbury encourages parents to savor not only their children's "firsts"--like first steps and first words--but the "lasts" as well. With the tenderness of a mother speaking directly to her child, Karen reminds us not to miss last days of kindergarten and last at bats in Little League amidst the whirlwind of life. Adapted from a poem in Rejoice,  mothers and grandmothers everywhere will identify with the tenderhearted reflections in Let Me Hold You Longer. An ideal gift book for special occasions from baby showers to graduations. Now includes a bonus CD read by Karen!
title: Let Me Hold You Longer
